statement.text: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are high-flow vascular anomalies characterized by direct arteriovenous shunting without an intervening capillary bed (nidus), progressing through Schobinger stages from quiescence to decompensation, requiring complete nidus elimination through combined embolization and resection for cure.
statement.formal: AVM = High_Flow + AV_Shunt_Without_Capillary_Bed + Nidus + Schobinger_Staging + Requires_Complete_Nidus_Elimination

explanation.intuition: AVMs are like direct shortcuts between arteries and veins that shouldn't exist. Blood flows too fast through these abnormal connections (the nidus) instead of going through normal capillaries. They often seem stable for years, then suddenly enlarge and cause problems after puberty, pregnancy, or trauma.
explanation.key_insight: The nidus is the key - partial treatment makes AVMs worse by stimulating angiogenesis. Embolization alone without resection leads to recurrence. The goal must be complete nidus elimination, which usually requires combined embolization followed by surgical resection. Some AVMs are unresectable and require palliative management.
explanation.technical_details: AVMs are present at birth but may not be evident until triggered by puberty, pregnancy, trauma, or incomplete treatment. Pathophysiology: arteriovenous shunting causes venous arterialization, tissue ischemia from arterial steal, and high-output cardiac state if large. Schobinger staging: I (quiescence - warmth, pink-blue, AV shunting on Doppler), II (expansion - pulsation, thrill, bruit, tortuous veins), III (destruction - pain, ulceration, bleeding, steal phenomena), IV (decompensation - high-output cardiac failure). Imaging: Doppler shows high-velocity low-resistance flow; MRI/MRA for extent; angiography for treatment planning. Treatment: embolization (ethanol, Onyx, coils) to devascularize, followed by surgical resection within 24-72 hours while nidus still devascularized. Proximal ligation is CONTRAINDICATED - stimulates collateral recruitment.

pathophysiology.lesion: Direct arteriovenous connections without capillary bed
pathophysiology.nidus: Core of abnormal vessels - key target for treatment

Stage_I.name: Quiescence
Stage_I.features: Warmth, pink-blue discoloration, AV shunting on Doppler

Stage_II.name: Expansion
Stage_II.features: Enlargement, pulsation, thrill, bruit, tortuous veins

Stage_III.name: Destruction
Stage_III.features: Pain, ulceration, bleeding, dystrophic skin, steal ischemia

diagnosis.duplex: High-velocity, low-resistance arterial flow; arterialized veins
diagnosis.angiography: Defines feeding arteries, nidus, draining veins - for treatment planning

treatment.principle: Complete nidus elimination - partial treatment worsens

embolization.role: Devascularize before resection; palliative if unresectable

definition.@value: High-flow vascular malformation characterized by direct arteriovenous shunting through a nidus without an intervening capillary bed, progressing through Schobinger stages and requiring complete nidus elimination for cure.

learning_objectives: Understand why partial treatment worsens AVMs
clinical_pearls: AVM = HIGH-FLOW - warm, thrill, bruit (vs VM = low-flow, compressible)
NEVER ligate proximal vessels - stimulates collateral recruitment and makes it worse
Nidus is the key - must eliminate COMPLETELY for cure
Embolization alone = recurrence; embolization + resection = cure
Schobinger III (destruction) and IV (decompensation) require intervention
Triggers: puberty, pregnancy, trauma, partial treatment
